conclusion: Use the ideal gas law PV = nRT to determine the temperature at state B.
Ideal gas law variables: P is pressure, V is volume, n is moles, R is ideal gas constant, T is temperature in Kelvin.
Ideal gas constant R = 8.314 J/mol K.
Temperature at state A is given as 27°C.
Convert temperature from Celsius to Kelvin using T(K) = T(°C) + 273.15.
Temperature at state A in Kelvin is T_A = 27 + 273.15 = 300.15 K.
From the p-V diagram: At state A, P_A = 3 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 1 x 10^-3 m^3.
From the p-V diagram: At state B, P_B = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 1 x 10^-3 m^3.
Set up the ideal gas law equations for states A and B: P_A V_A = nRT_A and P_B V_B = nRT_B.
Divide the equation for state B by the equation for state A: (P_B V_B) / (P_A V_A) = T_B / T_A.
Substitute known values into the equation: (1 x 10^5 x 1 x 10^-3) / (3 x 10^5 x 1 x 10^-3) = T_B / 300.15.
Simplify the left side of the equation: 1/3 = T_B / 300.15.
The temperature of the gas at state B is 100.05 K.
